poem:
Title: "From the Bay to a Borough"

In the crevices of Clapham - a tale unfolds,
of a bard bleeding ink into London's mould.
He, who once danced with words on Frisco streets,
finds solace in a city where history and future meets.
Armistead, erstwhile nomad, finds his 'home' in an unexpected land,
scripting symphonies of change, with a timeless pen in hand.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Look at your country! It’s amazing’: Armistead Maupin on moving to London Armistead Maupin is just where he wants to be. But that’s not where you might expect. The writer who made his name as the bard of San Francisco – or at least an earlier incarnation of it, featuring gay jockey-short dance competitions, weed‑smoking landladies and, crucially, affordable housing – is now happily ensconced in south London. A 1930s terrace in Clapham feels so much like home that he looks". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: ‘Look at your country! It’s amazing’: Armistead Maupin on moving to London Armistead Maupin is just where he wants to be. But that’s not where you might expect. A 1930s terrace in Clapham feels so much like home that he looks
